The Hodge conjecture

Apr 29, 2020

In this post, I would like to talk about the Hodge conjecture. Elden just gave the last lecture for his class, where he talked about the Hodge conjecture. Recall that the integral Hodge conjecture states that if is a projective variety over , then is surjective. A counterexample to this conjecture was found by Atiyah and Hirzebruch, and later Totaro gave an interpretation in terms of cobordism. Elden talked about this construction of Totaro’s, and its interpretation by Levine and Morel.

Here’s how this goes. The whole story fits into the following very nice diagram.

(Here, is the Lazard ring (and the final isomorphism is very nontrivial). Also, the bottom right vertical map lands in , not .) I have no idea how to draw diagonal arrows, so let me summarize what they should be in the following bullet points.

  • Totaro constructed a map which makes the resulting triangle in the above diagram commute. In other words, Totaro lifts the cycle class map to . Roughly speaking, this comes from resolution of singularities. It’s important to remark here that the map
  • Levine and Morel give a construction of Totaro’s map by actually constructing a map splitting the bottom left vertical map. This is badass, because no such thing is true in topology.

Roughly speaking, the Levin-Morel map takes , and sends it to , where is a resolution of singularities of (given by an iterated sequence of blowups with smooth centers). Then the blowup formula in motivic cobordism is supposed to imply that the algebraic cobordism class of is independent of the choice of resolution of singularities.

The reason this fails topologically — which, by the above discussion, could be loosely interpreted as the failure of Landweber exactness for — is because topological resolution of singularities fails. This was observed by Thom in his thesis (the one that solved Steenrod’s problem). To say this precisely, let me say what “topological resolution of singularities” means: say that (resp ) has topological resolution of singularities if there is a smooth oriented (possibly unoriented in mod two cohomology) closed manifold such that is sent to under (or ). Thom showed that there is a splitting , and . So, at least every mod cohomology class admits a topological resolution of singularities, and similarly for every -local cohomology class.

One natural question to ask, therefore, is whether there are similar maps from motivic and to the motivic analogues of and . These motivic analogues appaear in Example 16.23 of this paper. At least for , there is a universal property (apparing in as-yet-unpublished work of some folks, so I will not elaborate; I think their work can be extended to , but I haven’t gotten around to working this out yet). But I think it’s true that (motivically) has (at least over a base scheme where is invertible).

The other type of question one can ask, of course, is as follows. Upon -localizing, there’s a filtration of (and ) by ’s. Let be a projective variety, and consider the cycle class map . Given , you can ask whether is algebraic. But Levine-Morel-Totaro tells us that actually has to lift to (ok, ok, ). If does not lift to , then we’re done for! So, given a class , you can try to ask what the maximal is to which it lifts.

Here’s something to note. In his thesis, Wilson showed that contains as a factor if . Therefore, if , then the map is surjective. Therefore, the Levine-Morel-Totaro obstruction vanishes for if lifts to with such that .
